 To deploy Alluxio in production, we highly recommend running Alluxio masters in
 [High Availability]({{ '/en/deploy/Running-Alluxio-On-a-HA-Cluster.html' | relativize_url }}) mode.
 
 ## Prerequisites
 
-* To deploy a Alluxio cluster, first [download](https://alluxio.io/download) the pre-compiled Alluxio
-  binary file, extract the tarball with the below command, and copy the extracted directory to all
-  nodes (including nodes running masters and workers).
+* To deploy a Alluxio cluster, first [download](https://alluxio.io/download) the pre-compiled
+  Alluxio binary file, extract the tarball with the below command, and copy the extracted 
+  directory to all nodes (including nodes running masters and workers).
   
   ```console
   $ tar -xvzpf alluxio-{{site.ALLUXIO_VERSION_STRING}}-bin.tar.gz
   ```
   
-* Enable SSH login without password from master node to worker nodes. You can add a public SSH key for
-  the host into `~/.ssh/authorized_keys`. See [this tutorial](http://www.linuxproblem.org/art_9.html) for more details.
-* TCP traffic across all nodes is allowed. For basic functionality make sure RPC port (default :19998) is open
-  on all nodes.

replies.bodyText: Further down we mention starting Alluxio with ./bin/alluxio-start.sh all SudoMount. For consistency, I think we can put this as a requirement. Alternatively, I can add more to the start section to explain how to avoid sudo.
replies.author: ns1123

replies.bodyText: I don't think it's a hard requirement especially because it depends on configuration and mounting (NVMe?). sudo is only ever required to actually make the mount which is separate from Alluxio functionality. I think it is ok to put that sudo is required if users want our scripts to mount the workers' storage directories for them
